text: ਅਗਮੁ ਅਨੰਤੁ ਅਨਾਦਿ ਆਦਿ ਜਿਸੁ ਕੋਇ ਨ ਜਾਣੈ ॥

translation.text: The Lord is Inaccessible, Infinite, Eternal and Primordial; no one knows His beginning.

transliteration.text: agam anant anād ād jis kōi n jānai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਸਿਵ ਬਿਰੰਚਿ ਧਰਿ ਧ੍ਯਾਨੁ ਨਿਤਹਿ ਜਿਸੁ ਬੇਦੁ ਬਖਾਣੈ ॥

translation.text: Shiva and Brahma meditate on Him; the Vedas describe Him again and again.

transliteration.text: siv biranch dhar dhyān nitah jis bēd bakhānai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਨਿਰੰਕਾਰੁ ਨਿਰਵੈਰੁ ਅਵਰੁ ਨਹੀ ਦੂਸਰ ਕੋਈ ॥

translation.text: The Lord is Formless, beyond hate and vengeance; there is no one else like Him.

transliteration.text: nirankār niravair avar nahī dūsar kōī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਭੰਜਨ ਗੜ੍ਹਣ ਸਮਥੁ ਤਰਣ ਤਾਰਣ ਪ੍ਰਭੁ ਸੋਈ ॥

translation.text: He creates and destroys - He is All-powerful; God is the Boat to carry all across.

transliteration.text: bhanjan garhan samath taran tāran prabh sōī .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਨਾਨਾ ਪ੍ਰਕਾਰ ਜਿਨਿ ਜਗੁ ਕੀਓ ਜਨੁ ਮਥੁਰਾ ਰਸਨਾ ਰਸੈ ॥

translation.text: He created the world in its various aspects; His humble servant Mat'huraa delights in His Praises.

transliteration.text: nānā prakār jin jag kīō jan mathurā rasanā rasai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਸ੍ਰੀ ਸਤਿ ਨਾਮੁ ਕਰਤਾ ਪੁਰਖੁ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਚਿਤਹ ਬਸੈ ॥੧॥

translation.text: Sat Naam, the Great and Supreme True Name of God, the Personification of Creativity, dwells in the Consciousness of Guru Raam Daas. ||1||

transliteration.text: srī sat nām karatā purakh gur rāmadās chitah basai .1.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਗੁਰੂ ਸਮਰਥੁ ਗਹਿ ਕਰੀਆ ਧ੍ਰੁਵ ਬੁਧਿ ਸੁਮਤਿ ਸਮ੍ਹਾਰਨ ਕਉ ॥

translation.text: I have grasped hold of the All-powerful Guru; He has made my mind steady and stable, and embellished me with clear consciousness.

transliteration.text: gurū samarath gah karīā dhruv budh sumat samhāran kau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਫੁਨਿ ਧ੍ਰੰਮ ਧੁਜਾ ਫਹਰੰਤਿ ਸਦਾ ਅਘ ਪੁੰਜ ਤਰੰਗ ਨਿਵਾਰਨ ਕਉ ॥

translation.text: And, His Banner of Righteousness waves proudly forever, to defend against the waves of sin.

transliteration.text: phun dhranm dhujā phaharant sadā agh punj tarang nivāran kau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਮਥੁਰਾ ਜਨ ਜਾਨਿ ਕਹੀ ਜੀਅ ਸਾਚੁ ਸੁ ਅਉਰ ਕਛੂ ਨ ਬਿਚਾਰਨ ਕਉ ॥

translation.text: His humble servant Mat'hraa knows this as true, and speaks it from his soul; there is nothing else to consider.

transliteration.text: mathurā jan jān kahī jī sāch s aur kashū n bichāran kau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਹਰਿ ਨਾਮੁ ਬੋਹਿਥੁ ਬਡੌ ਕਲਿ ਮੈ ਭਵ ਸਾਗਰ ਪਾਰਿ ਉਤਾਰਨ ਕਉ ॥੨॥

translation.text: In this Dark Age of Kali Yuga, the Lord's Name is the Great Ship, to carry us all across the terrifying world-ocean, safely to the other side. ||2||

transliteration.text: har nām bōhith badau kal mai bhav sāgar pār utāran kau .2.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਸੰਤਤ ਹੀ ਸਤਸੰਗਤਿ ਸੰਗ ਸੁਰੰਗ ਰਤੇ ਜਸੁ ਗਾਵਤ ਹੈ ॥

translation.text: The Saints dwell in the Saadh Sangat, the Company of the Holy; imbued with pure celestial love, they sing the Lord's Praises.

transliteration.text: santat hī satasangat sang surang ratē jas gāvat hai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਧ੍ਰਮ ਪੰਥੁ ਧਰਿਓ ਧਰਨੀਧਰ ਆਪਿ ਰਹੇ ਲਿਵ ਧਾਰਿ ਨ ਧਾਵਤ ਹੈ ॥

translation.text: The Support of the Earth has established this Path of Dharma; He Himself remains lovingly attuned to the Lord, and does not wander in distraction.

transliteration.text: dhram panth dhariō dharanīdhar āp rahē liv dhār n dhāvat hai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਮਥੁਰਾ ਭਨਿ ਭਾਗ ਭਲੇ ਉਨ੍ਹ ਕੇ ਮਨ ਇਛਤ ਹੀ ਫਲ ਪਾਵਤ ਹੈ ॥

translation.text: So speaks Mat'huraa: those blessed with good fortune receive the fruits of their minds' desires.

transliteration.text: mathurā bhan bhāg bhalē unh kē man ishat hī phal pāvat hai .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਰਵਿ ਕੇ ਸੁਤ ਕੋ ਤਿਨ੍ਹ ਤ੍ਰਾਸੁ ਕਹਾ ਜੁ ਚਰੰਨ ਗੁਰੂ ਚਿਤੁ ਲਾਵਤ ਹੈ ॥੩॥

translation.text: Those who focus their consciousness on the Guru's Feet, they do not fear the judgement of Dharamraj. ||3||

transliteration.text: rav kē sut kō tinh trās kahā j charann gurū chit lāvat hai .3.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਨਿਰਮਲ ਨਾਮੁ ਸੁਧਾ ਪਰਪੂਰਨ ਸਬਦ ਤਰੰਗ ਪ੍ਰਗਟਿਤ ਦਿਨ ਆਗਰੁ ॥

translation.text: The Immaculate, Sacred Pool of the Guru is overflowing with the waves of the Shabad, radiantly revealed in the early hours before the dawn.

transliteration.text: niramal nām sudhā parapūran sabad tarang pragatit din āgar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਗਹਿਰ ਗੰਭੀਰੁ ਅਥਾਹ ਅਤਿ ਬਡ ਸੁਭਰੁ ਸਦਾ ਸਭ ਬਿਧਿ ਰਤਨਾਗਰੁ ॥

translation.text: He is Deep and Profound, Unfathomable and utterly Great, eternally overflowing with all sorts of jewels.

transliteration.text: gahir ganbhīr athāh at bad subhar sadā sabh bidh ratanāgar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਸੰਤ ਮਰਾਲ ਕਰਹਿ ਕੰਤੂਹਲ ਤਿਨ ਜਮ ਤ੍ਰਾਸ ਮਿਟਿਓ ਦੁਖ ਕਾਗਰੁ ॥

translation.text: The Saint-swans celebrate; their fear of death is erased, along with the accounts of their pain.

transliteration.text: sant marāl karah kantūhal tin jam trās mitiō dukh kāgar .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਕਲਜੁਗ ਦੁਰਤ ਦੂਰਿ ਕਰਬੇ ਕਉ ਦਰਸਨੁ ਗੁਰੂ ਸਗਲ ਸੁਖ ਸਾਗਰੁ ॥੪॥

translation.text: In this Dark Age of Kali Yuga, the sins are taken away; the Blessed Vision of the Guru's Darshan is the Ocean of all peace and comfort. ||4||

transliteration.text: kalajug durat dūr karabē kau darasan gurū sagal sukh sāgar .4.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਜਾ ਕਉ ਮੁਨਿ ਧ੍ਯਾਨੁ ਧਰੈ ਫਿਰਤ ਸਗਲ ਜੁਗ ਕਬਹੁ ਕ ਕੋਊ ਪਾਵੈ ਆਤਮ ਪ੍ਰਗਾਸ ਕਉ ॥

translation.text: For His Sake, the silent sages meditated and focused their consciousness, wandering all the ages through; rarely, if ever, their souls were enlightened.

transliteration.text: jā kau mun dhyān dharai phirat sagal jug kabah k kōū pāvai ātam pragās kau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਬੇਦ ਬਾਣੀ ਸਹਿਤ ਬਿਰੰਚਿ ਜਸੁ ਗਾਵੈ ਜਾ ਕੋ ਸਿਵ ਮੁਨਿ ਗਹਿ ਨ ਤਜਾਤ ਕਬਿਲਾਸ ਕੰਉ ॥

translation.text: In the Hymns of the Vedas, Brahma sang His Praises; for His Sake, Shiva the silent sage held his place on the Kailaash Mountain.

transliteration.text: bēd bānī sahit biranch jas gāvai jā kō siv mun gah n tajāt kabilās kanu .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਜਾ ਕੌ ਜੋਗੀ ਜਤੀ ਸਿਧ ਸਾਧਿਕ ਅਨੇਕ ਤਪ ਜਟਾ ਜੂਟ ਭੇਖ ਕੀਏ ਫਿਰਤ ਉਦਾਸ ਕਉ ॥

translation.text: For His Sake, the Yogis, celibates, Siddhas and seekers, the countless sects of fanatics with matted hair wear religious robes, wandering as detached renunciates.

transliteration.text: jā kau jōgī jatī sidh sādhik anēk tap jatā jūt bhēkh kīē phirat udās kau .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਸੁ ਤਿਨਿ ਸਤਿਗੁਰਿ ਸੁਖ ਭਾਇ ਕ੍ਰਿਪਾ ਧਾਰੀ ਜੀਅ ਨਾਮ ਕੀ ਬਡਾਈ ਦਈ ਗੁਰ ਰਾਮਦਾਸ ਕਉ ॥੫॥

translation.text: That True Guru, by the Pleasure of His Will, showered His Mercy upon all beings, and blessed Guru Raam Daas with the Glorious Greatness of the Naam. ||5||

transliteration.text: s tin satigur sukh bhāi kripā dhārī jī nām kī badāī daī gur rāmadās kau .5.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਨਾਮੁ ਨਿਧਾਨੁ ਧਿਆਨ ਅੰਤਰਗਤਿ ਤੇਜ ਪੁੰਜ ਤਿਹੁ ਲੋਗ ਪ੍ਰਗਾਸੇ ॥

translation.text: He focuses His Meditation deep within; the Embodiment of Light, He illuminates the three worlds.

transliteration.text: nām nidhān dhiān antaragat tēj punj tih lōg pragāsē .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਦੇਖਤ ਦਰਸੁ ਭਟਕਿ ਭ੍ਰਮੁ ਭਜਤ ਦੁਖ ਪਰਹਰਿ ਸੁਖ ਸਹਜ ਬਿਗਾਸੇ ॥

translation.text: Gazing upon the Blessed Vision of His Darshan, doubt runs away, pain is eradicated, and celestial peace spontaneously wells up.

transliteration.text: dēkhat daras bhatak bhram bhajat dukh parahar sukh sahaj bigāsē .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਸੇਵਕ ਸਿਖ ਸਦਾ ਅਤਿ ਲੁਭਿਤ ਅਲਿ ਸਮੂਹ ਜਿਉ ਕੁਸਮ ਸੁਬਾਸੇ ॥

translation.text: The selfless servants and Sikhs are always totally captivated by it, like bumble bees lured by the fragrance of the flower.

transliteration.text: sēvak sikh sadā at lubhit al samūh jiu kusam subāsē .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਬਿਦ੍ਯਮਾਨ ਗੁਰਿ ਆਪਿ ਥਪ੍ਯਉ ਥਿਰੁ ਸਾਚਉ ਤਖਤੁ ਗੁਰੂ ਰਾਮਦਾਸੈ ॥੬॥

translation.text: The Guru Himself established the Eternal Throne of Truth, in Guru Raam Daas. ||6||

transliteration.text: bidyamān gur āp thapyau thir sāchau takhat gurū rāmadāsai .6.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਤਾਰ੍ਯਉ ਸੰਸਾਰੁ ਮਾਯਾ ਮਦ ਮੋਹਿਤ ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤ ਨਾਮੁ ਦੀਅਉ ਸਮਰਥੁ ॥

translation.text: The Universe is intoxicated with the wine of Maya, but it has been saved; the All-powerful Guru has blessed it with the Ambrosial Nectar of the Naam.

transliteration.text: tāryau sansār māyā mad mōhit anmrit nām dīau samarath .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਫੁਨਿ ਕੀਰਤਿਵੰਤ ਸਦਾ ਸੁਖ ਸੰਪਤਿ ਰਿਧਿ ਅਰੁ ਸਿਧਿ ਨ ਛੋਡਇ ਸਥੁ ॥

translation.text: And, the Praiseworthy Guru is blessed with eternal peace, wealth and prosperity; the supernatural spiritual powers of the Siddhis never leave him.

transliteration.text: phun kīrativant sadā sukh sanpat ridh ar sidh n shōdai sath .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਦਾਨਿ ਬਡੌ ਅਤਿਵੰਤੁ ਮਹਾਬਲਿ ਸੇਵਕਿ ਦਾਸਿ ਕਹਿਓ ਇਹੁ ਤਥੁ ॥

translation.text: His Gifts are vast and great; His awesome Power is supreme. Your humble servant and slave speaks this truth.

transliteration.text: dān badau ativant mahābal sēvak dās kahiō ih tath .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Poet Mathura
author.description:
Poet Mathura [15th - 16th Century] was part of a group of eleven poets and singers known as Bhatts, who were all Vaishnavites, followers of Lord Rama and Lord Krishna, who had come to the congregation of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Sikh Guru, seeking spiritual solace.

Poet Mathura wrote seven hymns in praise of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Guru and seven hymns in praise of Guru Arjan Dev, the fifth Guru. He was the son of Poet Bhika, and brother of Poets Jalap and Kirat.

text: ਤਾਹਿ ਕਹਾ ਪਰਵਾਹ ਕਾਹੂ ਕੀ ਜਾ ਕੈ ਬਸੀਸਿ ਧਰਿਓ ਗੁਰਿ ਹਥੁ ॥੭॥੪੯॥

translation.text: One, upon whose head the Guru has placed His Hand - with whom should he be concerned? ||7||49||

transliteration.text: tāh kahā paravāh kāhū kī jā kai basīs dhariō gur hath .7.49.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood
